title: 112_hr1124
content:
The "Fairness in Taxation Act of 2011" is also known as the Fairness in Taxation Act. It increases tax rates for taxpayers with over $1,000,000 in taxable income. Tax rates for taxable income over $69,000 are as follows: 15% for income not over $69,000, $10,350 plus 28% for income over $69,000 but not over $139,350, $30,048 plus 31% for income over $139,350 but not over $212,300, $52,662.50 plus 36% for income over $212,300 but not over $379,150, and $112,728.50 plus 39.6% for income over $379,150 but not over $1,000,000. For taxable income over $1,000,000, the tax rates are as follows: $358,585.10 plus 45% of the excess over $1,000,000 for income not over $10,000,000, $4,408,585.10 plus 46% for income over $10,000,000 but not over $20,000,000, $9,008,585.10 plus 47% for income over $20,000,000 but not over $100,000,000, and $46,608,585.10 plus 48% for income over $100,000,000 but not over $1,000,000,000. For taxable income over $1,000,000, the tax rates are as follows: $478,608,585.10 plus 49% of the excess over $1,000,000,000 for heads of household. For taxable income over $1,000,000, the tax rates are as follows: $478,608,585.10 plus 49% of the excess over $1,000,000,000 for heads of household. If taxable income is not over $46,250, the tax is 15% of taxable income. Over $46,250 but not over $119,400, the tax is $6,937.50, plus 28% of the excess over $46,250. Over $119,400 but not over $193,350, the tax is $27,419.50, plus 31% of the excess over $119,400. Over $193,350 but not over $379,150, the tax is $50,344, plus 36% of the excess over $193,350. Over $379,150 but not over $1,000,000, the tax is $117,232, plus 39.6% of the excess over $379,150. For taxable income over $1,000,000, the tax rates are as follows:
- $363,088.60 plus 45% of the excess over $1,000,000
- $4,413,088.60 plus 46% of the excess over $10,000,000
- $9,013,088.60 plus 47% of the excess over $20,000,000
- $46,613,088.60 plus 48% of the excess over $100,000,000
- For income over $1,000,000,000, the tax rates continue. For taxable income over $1,000,000, the tax rates are as follows: $478,613,088.60, plus 49% of the excess over $1,000,000,000 for unmarried individuals. If taxable income is not over $34,500, the tax is 15% of taxable income. For income over $34,500 but not over $83,600, the tax is $5,175 plus 28% of the excess over $34,500. For income over $83,600 but not over $174,400, the tax is $18,923 plus 31% of the excess over $83,600. For income over $174,400 but not over $379,150, the tax is $47,071 plus 36% of the excess over $174,400. For income over $379,150 but not over $1,000,000, the tax is $120,781 plus 39.6% of the excess over $379,150. For taxable income over $1,000,000 but not over $10,000,000, the tax is $366,637.60 plus 45% of the excess. For income over $10,000,000 but not over $20,000,000, the tax is $4,416,637.60 plus 46% of the excess. For income over $20,000,000 but not over $100,000,000, the tax is $9,016,637.60 plus 47% of the excess. For income over $100,000,000 but not over $1,000,000,000, the tax is $46,616,637.60 plus 48% of the excess. The curr_chunk states that for married individuals filing separate returns, the tax table is amended to include a tax of $478,616,637.60 plus 49% of the excess over $1,000,000,000. For married individuals filing separate returns, the tax table includes a tax of $478,616,637.60 plus 49% of the excess over $1,000,000,000. The tax rates for taxable income range from 15% to 39.6% based on income brackets. For taxable income over $500,000 but not over $5,000,000, the tax is $178,458.30 plus 45% of the excess. For income over $5,000,000 but not over $10,000,000, the tax is $2,203,458.30 plus 46% of the excess. For income over $10,000,000 but not over $50,000,000, the tax is $4,503,458.30 plus 47% of the excess. For income over $50,000,000 but not over $500,000,000, the tax is $23,303,458.30 plus 48% of the excess. For income over $500,000,000, the tax is $239,303,458.30 plus 49% of the excess. The tax for income over $500,000,000 is $239,303,458.30 plus 49% of the excess. There is a special rule for capital gains for individuals with taxable income subject to at least a 45-percent rate bracket. The amendment reduces the net capital gain for the taxable year by the lesser of the excess or the net capital gain. The reduction is allocated between adjusted net capital gain, unrecaptured 1250 gain, and section 1202 gain. The effective date for these changes is for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2010.
